verses.text: Now it was two days before the Passover and the Feast of Unleavened Bread. The chief priests and the scribes were looking for a way to arrest Jesus by stealth and kill him.
verses.comment: The connection to Passover is critical—the feast remembering Israel's deliverance foreshadows Jesus as the true Passover Lamb (see 1 Cor. 5:7). The religious leaders' plot sets the stage for the fulfillment of prophecy (Isa. 53:3-5).

verses.text: For they said, 'Not during the festival, or the people might riot.'
verses.comment: The leaders feared the crowds. Jesus' popularity and the time of Passover, when Jerusalem was full of pilgrims, show the tension and drama leading to his Passion.

verses.text: And while he was in Bethany, in the house of Simon the leper, as he was reclining at table, a woman came with an alabaster jar of very expensive pure nard. She broke the jar and poured it on his head.
verses.comment: The woman's act is deeply symbolic—anointing was reserved for kings and priests (see 1 Sam. 16:13). Jesus is both high priest and king. This prefigures the sacraments and devotion in worship.

verses.text: But some were indignant and said to themselves, 'Why has this perfume been wasted like this?'
verses.comment: The apparent 'waste' is a misunderstanding of sacred devotion. True worship is never wasted when directed toward Christ.

verses.text: This perfume could have been sold for more than three hundred denarii, and the money given to the poor.' And they scolded her.
verses.comment: Three hundred denarii was about a year's wages. The text presents a choice: devotion to Christ versus pragmatic charity. Jesus' response will clarify what is most important.

verses.text: But Jesus said, 'Leave her alone. Why do you trouble her? She has done a beautiful thing to me.'
verses.comment: Jesus defends the woman's action as good and worthy of praise. Such acts of personal devotion are commended by him.

verses.text: For you always have the poor with you, and whenever you wish, you can do good for them. But you will not always have me.
verses.comment: Jesus is not dismissing care for the poor (see Deut. 15:11), but pointing to the unique moment of his presence. There is a priority here on worship of Christ in the flesh.

verses.text: She has done what she could; she has anointed my body beforehand for burial.
verses.comment: Her act foreshadows Jesus’ death and burial. Anointing for burial alludes to Jesus' acceptance of his mission (see Is. 53:9).

verses.text: Truly, I say to you, wherever the gospel is proclaimed throughout the whole world, what she has done will also be told in memory of her."
verses.comment: This promise shows the honor Jesus gives to sacrificial acts for his sake. The phrase 'in memory of her' echoes the Church’s remembrance in worship and commemoration.

verses.text: Then Judas Iscariot, who was one of the twelve, went to the chief priests to betray him to them.
verses.comment: Judas’s betrayal fulfills prophecy (see Ps. 41:9). His intimate position as 'one of the twelve' highlights the depth of the betrayal.

verses.text: When they heard it, they were glad and promised to give him money. And he sought an opportunity to betray him.
verses.comment: The promise of money links Judas’s betrayal with Zechariah's prophecy about being valued for thirty pieces of silver.

verses.text: On the first day of Unleavened Bread, when they sacrificed the Passover lamb, his disciples said to him, 'Where do you want us to go and prepare for you to eat the Passover?'
verses.comment: Jesus deliberately aligns the Last Supper with Passover, identifying himself as the true Passover Lamb.

verses.text: He sent two of his disciples and said to them, 'Go into the city, and a man carrying a jar of water will meet you. Follow him.'
verses.comment: The detailed instructions show Jesus’ foreknowledge, indicating his divine authority even in these arrangements.

verses.text: Wherever he enters, say to the owner of the house, 'The Teacher says, Where is my guest room where I may eat the Passover with my disciples?'
verses.comment: The phrase 'The Teacher' shows Jesus’ accepted and honored status among some in the city.

verses.text: And he will show you a large upper room furnished and ready. Make preparations for us there.'
verses.comment: This 'upper room' is significant—the early Church also gathered in an upper room (Acts 1:13), connecting the Last Supper to the Church’s origins.

verses.text: So the disciples went, entered the city, and found it just as he had told them. And they prepared the Passover.
verses.comment: The fulfillment of Jesus’ precise instructions further emphasizes his divine authority.

verses.text: When evening came, he arrived with the twelve.
verses.comment: The Last Supper begins—an event of central importance for Christian faith and worship.

verses.text: As they were reclining at the table and eating, Jesus said, 'Truly, I say to you, one of you who is eating with me will betray me.'
verses.comment: Sharing a meal represented close fellowship, which makes a betrayal at this moment especially shocking.

verses.text: They began to be sorrowful and to say to him one after another, 'Is it I?'
verses.comment: The disciples’ sorrow and questioning reflect their awareness of their own weakness—an honest humility before Christ.

verses.text: He said to them, 'It is one of the twelve, one who is dipping bread into the bowl with me.'
verses.comment: Sharing the same dish emphasized the closeness of the betrayer—fulfilling Psalm 41:9.

verses.text: For the Son of Man goes as it is written of him, but woe to that man by whom the Son of Man is betrayed! It would have been better for that man if he had not been born."
verses.comment: Jesus refers to predetermined prophecy about his suffering, yet also affirms Judas’s responsibility—a mystery regarding divine sovereignty and human choice.

verses.text: As they were eating, he took bread, and after blessing it, he broke it, gave it to them, and said, 'Take; this is my body.'
verses.comment: This verse records the institution of the Eucharist. Jesus identifies the bread as his body—a literal and spiritual mystery uniting believers across time. The language points to a sacramental reality, not merely symbolism.

verses.text: Then he took a cup, and after giving thanks, he gave it to them, and they all drank from it.
verses.comment: Sharing one cup implies unity and participation in Christ. The act anticipates the new covenant.

verses.text: And he said to them, 'This is my blood of the covenant, which is poured out for many.'
verses.comment: The reference to 'blood of the covenant' echoes Exodus 24:8. Jesus’ death establishes a new, everlasting covenant, fulfilling Jeremiah 31:31-34. Note the sacrificial and redemptive meaning here.

verses.text: Truly I say to you, I will never again drink of the fruit of the vine until that day when I drink it new in the kingdom of God."
verses.comment: This points to the heavenly banquet and Jesus’ return in glory. The Last Supper anticipates future fulfillment in God’s kingdom.

verses.text: When they had sung a hymn, they went out to the Mount of Olives.
verses.comment: The hymn likely refers to the Hallel Psalms, traditionally sung at Passover. Moving to the Mount of Olives fulfills Zechariah 14:4.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'You will all fall away, for it is written: "I will strike the shepherd, and the sheep will be scattered."'
verses.comment: Jesus quotes Zechariah 13:7, applying the prophecy to himself. He takes the title 'shepherd,' a role God reserved for himself (Ezek. 34), highlighting Jesus’ divine identity.

verses.text: But after I am raised up, I will go ahead of you to Galilee."
verses.comment: Jesus predicts his resurrection, affirming both his death and triumph over it. He will reunite with his followers, showing his role as the leader of a restored community.

verses.text: Peter said to him, 'Even if all fall away, I will not.'
verses.comment: Peter’s confidence is admirable but will soon falter. His leadership is apparent, anticipating his later restoration and role as a primary shepherd.

verses.text: Jesus said to him, 'Truly, I say to you, this very night, before the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times.'
verses.comment: Jesus’ foreknowledge points to his divinity. He is both merciful and truthful, foretelling Peter’s weakness with precision.

verses.text: But Peter said emphatically, 'If I must die with you, I will not deny you.' And they all said the same.
verses.comment: The disciples’ desire to stand with Jesus highlights their weakness and need for grace, soon apparent in their failure.

verses.text: They came to a place called Gethsemane. And he said to his disciples, 'Sit here while I pray.'
verses.comment: Gethsemane means 'oil press', a place symbolic of great pressure. Jesus’ agony here shows his true humanity and fulfillment of the suffering servant role.

verses.text: He took Peter, James, and John with him, and he began to be greatly distressed and troubled.
verses.comment: These three disciples often witnessed key events, highlighting their special role. Jesus’ deep sorrow reflects his true human experience.

verses.text: He said to them, 'My soul is very sorrowful, even to death. Remain here and keep watch.'
verses.comment: Echoes Psalm 42:6’s language of sorrow. Jesus invites his disciples to participate with him in prayer—a model for all believers.

verses.text: Going a little farther, he fell to the ground and prayed that, if it were possible, the hour might pass from him.
verses.comment: ‘The hour’ refers to his impending suffering and death, showing both his obedience and the genuine struggle faced in his humanity.

verses.text: And he said, 'Abba, Father, all things are possible for you. Remove this cup from me. Yet not what I will, but what you will.'
verses.comment: Jesus uses a term of intimacy with God ('Abba'), yet submits his will completely. The 'cup' is a symbol of God’s wrath and suffering (see Ps. 75:8). This teaches perfect obedience and filial trust.

verses.text: He came and found them sleeping, and he said to Peter, 'Simon, are you asleep? Could you not keep watch for one hour?'
verses.comment: Jesus addresses Peter by his original name, reminding him of his weakness without grace. The call to 'watch' prepares for the Church as a praying community.

verses.text: Watch and pray that you may not enter into temptation. The spirit is willing, but the flesh is weak."
verses.comment: Jesus’ words about prayer and temptation are foundational for Christian spiritual practice. All believers are called to persistent vigilance.

verses.text: Again he went away and prayed, saying the same words.
verses.comment: Repetition in prayer meets the depth of human anxiety—Jesus shows us perseverance and trust before the Father.

verses.text: And again he came and found them sleeping, for their eyes were heavy. And they did not know what to answer him.
verses.comment: Even the closest disciples fail to keep watch. Their inability reminds the reader of the necessity of divine grace.

verses.text: He came the third time and said to them, 'Are you still sleeping and resting? Enough! The hour has come. The Son of Man is betrayed into the hands of sinners.'
verses.comment: The 'third time' recalls Peter’s threefold denial and the completeness of failure. Jesus moves forward obediently to his passion.

verses.text: Rise, let us be going. See, my betrayer is at hand."
verses.comment: Jesus willingly faces his betrayer, showing control and obedience. He accepts the Father’s will even when it leads to suffering.

verses.text: Immediately, while he was still speaking, Judas came, one of the twelve, and with him a crowd with swords and clubs, from the chief priests, the scribes, and the elders.
verses.comment: Judas is again emphasized as 'one of the twelve', stressing the gravity of his betrayal. The crowd’s weapons underscore their misunderstanding of Jesus’ peaceful mission.

verses.text: Now the betrayer had given them a sign, saying, 'The one I kiss is the man. Arrest him and lead him away under guard.'
verses.comment: A kiss, a sign of affection, is used for betrayal. This emphasizes the contrast between outward signs and inward intentions.

verses.text: When he came, he went up to him at once and said, 'Rabbi!' and kissed him.
verses.comment: Judas addresses Jesus as 'Rabbi', an acknowledgment of his authority, even as he betrays him.

verses.text: They laid hands on him and arrested him.
verses.comment: The arrest fulfills Jesus' prediction and the prophecies of the suffering servant (Isaiah 53).

verses.text: But one of those who stood by drew his sword, struck the servant of the high priest, and cut off his ear.
verses.comment: The impulse to defend Jesus by violence is rebuked in other Gospels. Here, the focus is on the event itself, highlighting the tension of the moment.

verses.text: Jesus said to them, 'Have you come out as against a robber, with swords and clubs to capture me?'
verses.comment: Jesus exposes the injustice of their approach. Though completely innocent, he is treated as a criminal.

verses.text: Day after day I was with you in the temple teaching, and you did not seize me. But let the Scriptures be fulfilled."
verses.comment: Jesus interprets his arrest as fulfillment of Scripture. He is aware of God’s sovereign plan, and submits to it willingly.

verses.text: And they all left him and fled.
verses.comment: Just as Jesus predicted, the disciples abandon him. This underlines Jesus’ utter loneliness in suffering for humanity.

verses.text: A certain young man was following him, wearing nothing but a linen cloth. They seized him,
verses.comment: Many believe this young man may be Mark himself. The linen cloth may allude to burial customs, symbolizing a willing but incomplete commitment.

verses.text: but he left the linen cloth and ran away naked.
verses.comment: His flight, like the disciples, shows human frailty. The image of nakedness represents shame and abandonment, reminiscent of Adam's original sin (Genesis 3:7).

verses.text: They led Jesus to the high priest, and all the chief priests, elders, and scribes came together.
verses.comment: Jesus is tried before the highest Jewish authorities, fulfilling his prophecy of being rejected by the elders (Mark 8:31).

verses.text: Peter followed him at a distance, right into the courtyard of the high priest. He sat with the guards and warmed himself at the fire.
verses.comment: Peter’s struggle exemplifies a struggle between fear and loyalty—a moment of both hope and human weakness.

verses.text: Now the chief priests and the whole council were seeking testimony against Jesus to put him to death, but they found none.
verses.comment: Their inability to find testimony shows Jesus’ innocence under the Law.

verses.text: For many bore false witness against him, but their testimonies did not agree.
verses.comment: Violations of the ninth commandment abound, highlighting Jesus as the righteous sufferer wronged by men.

verses.text: Some stood up and gave this false testimony against him:
verses.comment: The trial's corruption is made clear by bringing forward false witnesses.

verses.text: "We heard him say, 'I will destroy this temple made with hands, and in three days I will build another, not made with hands.'"
verses.comment: They twist Jesus’ own words (see John 2:19). 'Not made with hands' points beyond the physical building—the foundational reality of the Church Jesus establishes.

verses.text: Yet even then their testimony did not agree.
verses.comment: Different stories from witnesses expose the trial as a violation of justice and the Law.

verses.text: The high priest stood up in the middle and asked Jesus, 'Have you no answer to make? What is it that these men testify against you?'
verses.comment: Confronted with falsehood, Jesus maintains silence, fulfilling Isaiah 53:7, 'He was oppressed... yet he opened not his mouth.'

verses.text: But he was silent and made no answer. Again the high priest asked him, 'Are you the Christ, the Son of the Blessed?'
verses.comment: The high priest directly asks whether Jesus claims messianic and divine status. 'The Blessed' was a respectful way to refer to God.

verses.text: Jesus said, 'I am, and you will see the Son of Man seated at the right hand of Power and coming with the clouds of heaven.'
verses.comment: Jesus’s 'I am' echoes God’s name in Exodus 3:14 and Daniel 7:13-14’s description of a divine figure. By claiming to sit at God’s right hand, Jesus directly affirms his divinity and messianic office.

verses.text: And the high priest tore his garments and said, 'What further witnesses do we need?'
verses.comment: The act of tearing garments signified shock at blasphemy, but ironically testifies to the reality of Jesus’ claim.

verses.text: You have heard his blasphemy. What is your decision?' And they all condemned him as deserving death.
verses.comment: Jesus is condemned for claiming equality with God, affirming that his divinity was understood by his contemporaries—even as they reject it.

verses.text: Some began to spit on him, to blindfold him, and to strike him, saying to him, 'Prophesy!' And the guards received him with blows.
verses.comment: Their abuse fulfills scripture (Isa. 50:6). The humiliation of the Messiah paradoxically becomes the means of salvation.

verses.text: While Peter was below in the courtyard, one of the servant girls of the high priest came,
verses.comment: Peter’s threefold denial is prepared by these conversations. Even leaders can fall, yet restoration is possible, as Peter’s later story shows.

verses.text: and seeing Peter warming himself, she looked at him and said, 'You also were with the Nazarene, Jesus.'
verses.comment: Peter is identified as a follower of Jesus, challenging his loyalty in front of others.

verses.text: But he denied it, saying, 'I neither know nor understand what you are saying.' And he went out into the gateway, and the rooster crowed.
verses.comment: The first denial and the rooster’s crow remind us of Jesus’ prophecy, emphasizing God’s foreknowledge.

verses.text: And the servant girl, seeing him, began again to say to those standing around, 'This man is one of them.'
verses.comment: Peter is publicly challenged about his association with Jesus.

verses.text: But again he denied it. And after a little while, those standing by said to Peter again, 'Surely you are one of them, for you are also a Galilean.'
verses.comment: Peter’s accent betrays him as a Galilean—another indicator of his connection to Jesus.

verses.text: But he began to curse and to swear, 'I do not know this man of whom you speak.'
verses.comment: Peter’s denial escalates, yet it is not the end of his story. There is hope for restoration after failure.

verses.text: And immediately the rooster crowed a second time. Peter remembered the word Jesus had said to him, 'Before the rooster crows twice, you will deny me three times.' And he broke down and wept.
verses.comment: Peter's tears show genuine repentance. This foreshadows Jesus' forgiveness and his role as a restored leader of the community of faith.
